glossdef.para: The Administrator User oversees the entire system. He/she will maintain configuration parameters, manage user accounts, and maintain general operation of the system.

Analysis conditions are used to analyze data using analysis trees. Most analyses compare one or more conditions. An analysis condition contains data for at least one or more gene chips. When a condition contains more than one chip, the chips should be generally biological or technical replicates. Most analysis conditions correspond directly to an experimental condition and are typically created automatically when a user creates an analysis tree for a specific study. However, users may create their own analysis conditions. This is useful when grouping data in a non-default configuration or for grouping user uploaded data (as such data does not belong to a study).

There are many kinds of files involved in running analyses using analysis trees. These files are called analysis files. They include an input file that contains relevant chip data in a specific format, intermediate data files that pass data from one analysis to another, and result files that contain the results of each analysis module. Data on the interpretation of analysis result files are included in the help for each analysis.

Analysis sets are used to analyze data using analysis trees. An analysis set should consist of one or more analysis conditions. Most analysis sets are created automatically when a user creates an analysis tree. If the user specifies a specific array study as input, the analysis set will be created with the analysis conditions corresponding to the experimental conditions associated with the study. Users can create their own analysis sets. This is useful when grouping data in a non-default configuration or for grouping user uploaded data (as such data does not belong to a study).
The center or facility in charge of ordering chips and performing microarray gene expression experiments.

The Array Center Staff User is responsible for performing microarray experiments. This type of user will manage orders, hybridize chips, collect and upload chip data to the &product; system, and bill for services as appropriate.

An analysis (module) is an analysis unit that performs a certain analysis function based on an input data set; it also typically produces one or more output data files for interpretation and/or for the use of other connecting analysis modules. Typical analysis modules perform statistical calculations, functional/annotational analysis, and formatting data. Analysis modules can be written in many languages, as long as they can be successfully run from the command line on a Linux system. New analysis modules must be added by an administrator user. Current analyses are written in Perl and R. If the output from one analysis can be used as input to another analysis, they can be chained together in a tree.

glossentry.glossdef: An analysis tree corresponds to an integrated scheme of data analysis designed by each user. Each tree requires input, produces output, and performs a variety of calculations and analyses on the input data based on the nodes of analysis modules constructed in the tree. Each node can be chosen and defined from any analysis modules compatible with connecting nodes.

glossdef.para: A request for an array order is initiated by a &product; member user and submitted to the array center staff user for processing. It consists of a request to have samples hybridized to gene chips. The array center staff user generates the array order for the member user and then follows through with the work request once the member user has supplied all required information pertaining to the request.

Defined by the member user, an array study is a way of defining and describing a project being worked on by a particular member user and/or his/her group. An array study is the main logical entity that can hold all experimental conditions under a coherent study theme. More than one array order can be associated with a single array study. Additionally, you can add new experimental conditions to an array study as time passed.
Biological Replicates are different biological subjects under a same experimental or treatment condition that can show individual sampling variability of the target population.

A type of parameter used by criteria files. A categorical parameter is a categorization that has a finite number of distinct options. An example of such a parameter is gender, which has two levels of option "male" and "female".

cDNA (complementary DNA) is DNA that is reverse-transcribed from an mRNA template. cDNA microarrays are one of widely-used microarray technologies for measuring gene expression. Currently, &product; does not support the data analysis from this platform; this support is planned to be developed in 2005. &product; currently supports the Affymetrix GeneChip data.

A small (a few centimeters on each side) glass or other solid surface on which thousands of immobilized oligonucleotide probes (or cDNA clones) have been synthesized or robotically deposited in a predetermined array, so that automated recording of fluorescence from each of the positions may be easily determined. Also called an array, an array, or a microarray.

Each chip has a cost associated with it. The price is set when the layout is added and cannot be modified except through direct interaction with the database. The chip cost is used in calculating the bill for an array order.

When the array center staff user runs the array experiment the results are stored in chip data files. Once the array center staff user loads the data, these files are available for download. File formats may include:
cel
CEL files contain intensity values of all individual (perfect-match and mis-match) probes on an array
dat
an chip image file including information on pixel intensities, grid coordinates, and scan parameters
chp
the CHP file contains the analysis results with one summary intensity value for each probe set from the probe pairs on the set (by Tukey's bi-weight statistics); this file can be obtained by the GeneChip Operating Software, GCOS 1.0 (January `05)
exp
The EXP file contains experiment information as captured by GCOS
txt
data file containing probe set signals (equivalent to CHP file)
cab
a compilation of some of the other files generated by GCOS software

This is the initial location (actual or parent directory) of the chip data files. The array center staff places data files in this directory (or a subdirectory of this directory) prior to loading data. The &product; administrator must agree on this path with the array center staff and set the "Chip Data Path" field in the Configure &product; accordingly.

Each type of chip has an associated name that is set by the administrator user when the layout for that chip is loaded. If the chip is an Affymetrix GeneChip, the &product; name must correspond to the name specified in the rpt file (under "Probe Array Type") for data to load correctly. Otherwise a chip type mismatch error is detected. Administrators may specify additional information about the chip in parenthesis behind the chip name if necessary.
For example, the Affymetrix name for the P.Aeruginoas chip is "Pae_G1a". The &product; name is "Pae_G1a (p.aeruginoas)."

Chip replicates are the technically replicated arrays (or replicated hybridizations) with the same RNA samples. This kind of replication is useful to identify many false positives in microarray data analysis.

Installations that support an array center may not wish to allow public accounts on that installation. As public accounts can be created automatically and public users can upload files and run analyses there are security implications to having public user accounts. For this reason, a companion installation can be specified in the &product; Configuration. Companion installations should be completely separate installations (on different hardware) that support complementary user types.

A type of parameter used by criteria files. A continuous parameter is a categorization that has a range of options. Grouping based on continuous parameters tends to use less than and greater than operators. An example of such a parameter is age. Grouping could occur based on age ranges.

A criteria file is a file uploaded by the user that defines associations between their data. The criteria file can be used (via the Create new analysis condition and the Create new set of conditions links) to create analysis conditions and analysis sets based on specific criteria. For instance, the criteria file might contain gender information for all of your hybridizations. You could then create an analysis condition that contained all data associated with females and an analysis condition for all data associated with males.

This user is created by default by the geoss_initialize script. The default public user is a special user in that all users are a part of the public group. This means that data sets loaded for the default public user is accessible to all. This is intended for use in loading external data sets that other users may wish to analyze.
Studies consist of one or more experiment conditions. An experiment condition is the group of chips under the same experimental/treatment condition in a microarray study. (add example)
GCOS is freely available Affymetrix software used for working with its GeneChip data.

This file contains the password for the Postgres User and allows the web application to access the database. The file is readable only by the Linux user who runs the web server. To determine the location of the file, check the value for WEB_DIR under the &product; Installation Information link. The file is located in the directory shown there and has the filename .geoss.

This is the unique identifier for a &product; user. All users have a &product; login id and use it to login to the system. The id is selected by the administrator when the user account is created and is typically a short combination of letters and numbers.

note.para: Public users select their own &product; login id unless it already exists in the system.

glossdef.para: Gene chip data describes the results of a gene chip experiment and contains information like signal intensity values. When the array center staff user loads the gene chip data, &product; stores it both in the database and in file format. Member users can download files from the View My Files link.
GeneX is the name of the original open source software that &product; is based on. See GeneX 2 for current information on GeneX.
GeneX-Va is the former name of &product;.

In &product;, each user has at least one group, and can define multiple groups, under which different users can be added with different access privileges (read or write) to specific array studies and data. Only the user who owns the full control on them, typically Principal Investigator (PI) user, can manipulate this group creation and access options. Users can belong to more than one group and users may own more than one group.
In &product;, "hybridization" refers to a gene chip or array that corresponds to a specific hybridization of a sample.

An inactive user is a user who has an account but has never logged in. In order to be considered inactive, a configurable number of days must have passed since the account was created. To determine the number of days on a given installation, check the "Number of days a new public user has to confirm their account" parameter under the Configure &product; link in &admin_home;.

A layout is information pertaining to an Affymetrix GeneChip probe array. The layout information describes which probes belong to probe sets on the array. Currently &product; only supports layouts for the Affymetrix technology. However, work is under way to incorporate cDNA data and its associated layouts.
Microarray Suite Software (MAS) is an Affymetrix product used for GeneChip data analysis, which is recently replaced by the GCOS software. See the Affymetrix specification for further information.

Minimum Information About A Microarray Experiment (MIAME) data describes information that is needed to enable the interpretation of the results of the experiment unambiguously and potentially to reproduce the experiment. MIAME is the current standard of microarray information defined by the international Microarray Gene Expression Data Society (MGED).

&product; is working towards MIAME compliance. Although researchers are not required to enter MIAME information, they are encouraged to provide MIAME information, particularly when publishing study data as it increases the usability of the study data.

A member user is a user who has access to array lab functionality, particularly placing array orders. Due to increased access, the identity of member users must be confirmed prior to creation of their accounts.

Each array order has an associated order number that is created when the array center staff user responds to an array order request. The numbering sequence was designed to meet the needs of the UVa array center. &order_number_rule;

Each array order has an associated order status. The status can be:
Incomplete
Array order has been generated, but is not configured in a valid way. &valid_order_config_rule;
Complete
Array order has been generated and as a valid configuration. The order has not yet been submitted to the array center to inform them that it is ready for processing. Submitted Array order has been submitted to the array center or to the special center administrator as appropriate.
Approved
The array order has been submitted and it has been approved. Note that many orders receive automatic approval. Only array orders that are associated with a special center that require manual approval do not receive automatic approval.
Finished
The array center has processed the order and loaded the gene chip data files.
&password_rule;

&product; store information in a Postgres database. If &product; is installed via an rpm install and following instructions for a generic install, then the name of the database will be "geoss". However, it is possible to install with a different database name, as may be the case with a developer installation. To confirm the name of the database that your &product; connects to, you can check the value of the DB_NAME setting under the &product; Installation Information link, if you have administrator access.

When we refer to the Postgres User, we mean the user defined in Postgres (as opposed to a &product; user or a Linux user) that has access to the Postgres Database. To confirm the name of the user that your installation uses to connect to the Postgres Database, you can check the value of the GEOSS_SU_USER setting under the &product; Installation Information link, if you have administrator access.

The primary (or principal) investigator (PI) is a member user who owns studies and their associated data. Every user must be associated with a PI (or several PIs), although the user can be PI and choose himself as PI. A typical setup involves a group with a PI, and several staff members. Staff members often define studies and orders and perform the majority of the interaction with &product;, but the data is still owned by the PI.

If a PI has several different studies and would like to set up different access privileges on each one, then the PI should create several groups using the Create a New Group link. Study permissions can then be set so that only members of a specific group can see the study using the Change group ownership and read/write permissions for existing array studies link. Similarly, permissions for array orders can be changed using the Change group ownership and read/write permissions for existing array orders link.
Each user is assigned a PI when their account is created. Only the Administrator can change these associations, which is done using the Manage PIs and Users link from &admin_home;.

Once a researcher has published their experiment results, they may wish to make the data available to the public. To do this, they enter relevant MIAMEinformation about the experiment and then request study publication. Once published, data is available to all through the View Public Data link from the &product; home page.

The Public Data Administrator is responsible for managing the publication of data. Once a user requests publication of experiment results, the public data administrator confirms publication details and makes the appropriate files available.

Public users have a subset of the functionality of Member Users. They can upload data and perform analyses, but they do not have access to array center functionality (placing array orders). As they do not need to have this kind of access, the identity of a public user does not need to be verified and they are able to create their own accounts.
Each array order must have one or more samples associated with it. Each sample must be associated with an experimental condition. A sample can be hybridized into more than one chip.

Sometimes there is a one-to-one correlation between experimental conditions and samples, but there can be many samples associated with the same experimental condition if the experiment design includes biological replicates.

A special center is an entity that has different billing or array processing needs than regular users. Users can be associated with multiple special centers, but array orders may only be associated with one special center.
For an overview of functionality available to special centers, see the Special Center Administrator Guide.
Users can be designated as a special center administrator. Special center administrators update center information, manage center members, and approve array orders associated with the special center.
For an overview of functionality available to special centers, see the Special Center Administrator Guide.

A special center member is a user who is associated with a special center. Special center members can choose to associate their array orders with the special center at the time of order creation. This may result in billing discounts or in the array order being routed through an approval process, depending on the configuration of the special center.

Species id must be specified when loading layouts. Species are associated with ids in the species table when &product; is installed. To determine the species id for a specific species, login to the database as the postgres user and examine the species table.

example.title: Determining a Species Id
example.programlisting:
$ psql geoss -d geoss Password: Welcome to psql 7.3.4-RH, the PostgreSQL interactive terminal.
Type: \copyright for distribution terms \h for help with SQL commands \? for help on internal slash commands \g or terminate with semicolon to execute query \q to quit
geoss=# select spc_pk, primary_scientific_name, common_names from species; spc_pk | primary_scientific_name | common_names --------+-------------------------------+-------------------------------------- 89 | Lycopodium clavatum | stag's-horn clubmoss 90 | Chondrus crispus | carrageen, Irish moss 5 | Saccharomyces cerevisiae | yeast
geoss=\q

glossdef.para: Replicates can be either different biological subjects or technical replicated hybridizations (or chips); these will result in different statistical analysis options and results. Consult to the GMB staff for more detailed description.
The University of Virginia is where &product; is created and maintained.

Users can upload several types of files. They can upload mas5 data files which they can then use with analysis trees. They can upload criteria files, which they can use to build analysis conditions and analysis sets. They can also upload files under the the generic "other" category. These files could then be made viewable to other users. Examples of such files might be write-ups on experiment data.
Note that administrators and special center administrators can also upload logo and icon files associated with special centers.

Currently, GEOSS supports the following user types:.
Public User
Member User
Array Center Staff User
Administrator
Additionally, it is possible for a user to be designated as special center administrator user. Note, however, that this is not a user type, but rather a designation, and such a user will also have one of the four user types mentioned above.
glossdef.note: Please note that the user type names have recently changed and you may encounter instances where the legacy user type is still in use. Specifically, "member users" used to be "experiment set providers", "Array Center Staff Users" used to be "curators", and "special center administrators" used to be "organization curators". The "public" user type has not changed.

glossdef.para: Individual &product; users own several kinds of files: chip data files, analysis files and uploaded files. These are the user data files.
